Mirian explains that she wants to become a professional in order to lift herself out of poverty and achieve a better position in society.
With her loan, she will buy more goods to continue satisfying her customers’ needs and augment her income.

loans.use: To acquire clothing to resell in her community.

loans.name: Karin

texts.es:
Karin is a teacher's aide, but she had to leave that work when she became pregnant. For that reason, she evaluated alternative vocations that would allow her to be at home with her baby . That's how, with the help of her mother in law Flor, she came to run an internet café, located in her own home.

The business boasts 5 computers and has been up and running for 7 months. During this time, she has lost a CD reader and a hard disk to robbery by bad clients. With the loans that she has requested, she has maintained the computers and replaced the stolen accessories.

Karin would like to add 4 additional computers and expand her business with a photocopy machine and a phone booth, eventually.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Karin es auxiliar de educación, pero tuvo que dejar esta labor debido a que salió embarazada. Por este motivo, evaluó nuevas alternativas de trabajo que le permitan estar en casa para cuidar a su bebe. Fue así que, con la ayuda de su suegra Flor, ella ahora administra una cabina de Internet, ubicada en su misma casa.

El negocio consta de 5 computadoras y ya viene funcionando 6 meses. En este tiempo, ya han sufrido robos de disquetera y lector de CD por parte de malos clientes. Con los préstamos que ha pedido, ella ha dado mantenimiento a las computadoras y ha repuesto los accesorios robados.

Karin quisiera aumentar 4 computadoras más y ampliar su negocio con fotocopiadora y locutorio.

loans.use: For the maintenance of the computers and the purchase of accessories

loans.name: Esperando En Dios (Hoping In God) Groups 5&6

texts.en:
Lislena, the group leader, is 28 years-old and has four children ages 4, 6, 7 and 10.  She lives in a batey (which is a very poor community) of Haitian families in El Seibo, Dominican Republic. Families that live in bateys have small houses generally made of scrap tin and wood; the best possible accommodation is a cement-block house.  These ¨houses¨ consist of only one room where the whole family lives together. To provide for her family, Lislena buys clothes in the city and then re-sells them for a profit in her batey and another neighboring batey.  
By receiving loans, she and other members of the Bank of Hope are better able to survive the economic fluctuations and frequent sicknesses that make work hard and volatile. Lislena hopes that this loan will help her continue to grow her business so that her family can improve their living situation.  She would love to own her own house someday and hopes to provide a good education for her children.
Lislena is a member of the Esperando en Dios (Hoping in God) group. The Bank of Hope with Esperanza International supports six groups in total, two of which are requesting new loans now.
Note: This is a group loan to 10 people.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to re-sell

loans.name: Thuy Mai's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thuy Mai, born in 1970 (ID Number: 10040024), wants to borrow 4,452,000VND to expand her hair salon. Beside this shop, she also sells drinks so she has a stable daily income. Her husband works in an advertising agent, earning stable income. Her family's average monthly income is 3,000,000VND (about 188USD). She likes to join this Fund because she can repay the loan on an installment basis. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. N. Thi Thu Huong (ID Number: 10040026), born in 1980, wants to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in selling furniture and electronic products.

Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Ngan (ID Number: 10040025), born in 1982, wants to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in a breakfast eatery.

Mrs. P. Thu N. (ID Number: 10040042), born in 1960, wants to borrow 2,204,000VND to invest in selling drinks.

Mrs. T. Thi Thu Ha (ID Number: 10040028), born in 1971, wants to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

The total amount requested is 1,075USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Ngô Thuý Mai, sinh năm 1970 (Ms 10040024), mức vay:4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư mở rộng hiệu uốn tóc. N.ài nghề uốn tóc, chị còn bán thêm hàng giải khát nên chị có thu nhập đều theo ngày. Chồng chị làm nghề quảng cáo với mức lương ổn định. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị khoảng 3.000.000 vnđ / tháng. Việc vay vốn trả dần là rất phù hợp với gia đình chị nên chị rất thích và mong muốn được vay vốn thường xuyên. Trong nhóm chị còn có: Nguyễn Thị Thu Hường(Ms 10040026), sinh năm 1980, mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để kinh doanh đồ nội thất, điện tử. Nguyễn Thị Thuý Ngân(Ms 10040025), sinh năm 1982, mức vay: 3.604.000 vnđ để bán hàng ăn sáng. P. Thị Nguyện(Ms 10040042), sinh năm 1960, mức vay 2.204.000 vnđ để đầu tư bán hàng giải khát. Trịnh Thị Thu Hà(Ms 10040028), sinh năm 1971, mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn.

loans.use: Invest in hair salon

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 48 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 16, 14, and 12 years old. She owns and has been running a small shop since 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Maria now hopes for a loan to buy more products for her business.

loans.use: To buy more products to increase her inventory

loans.name: Clara

texts.fr: Clara S., 56 ans, mariée est membre du banc villageois de Néma Sobeya depuis 6 ans. Elle achète des pagnes thioub tissés (pagnes tissés teintés) qu’elle revend. Les revenus tirés de son commerce lui permettent d’améliorer les conditions de vie et de santé de sa famille.<b> Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.<b/>
texts.en:
Clara S., 56, is married and has been a member of the village bank Néma Sobeya for 6 years. She buys woven lengths of cloth called "thioub" (hand-dyed lengths of a traditional textile) which she re-sells. The income from her business allows her to improve the living conditions and health of her family. She is requesting a loan that will be reimbursed at the end of 6 months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase and re-sale of lengths of textile called "thioub"

loans.name: Teung

texts.en: Teung L., 43, is married and lives with her five children in the Kampong Cham province. She work selling vegetables in the morning and soup in the evening and she makes about US$2.50 each day, while her husband works selling roasted eggs, making US$2.50 each day as well. Teung has requested a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike and a grill cart (that can cook the eggs) that can attach with the motorbike. This will allow them to travel and serve more customers.

loans.use: Teung would like to purchase a motorbike with a grill cart to expand her family business.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.es:
Bernardo  vive junto a sus dos hijos, con los cuales trabaja en su taller de confección de zapatillas y botines ubicado en una zona céntrica de la cuidad de La Paz .
 
Vive en la calle Gral  J. Sever de la zona Los Andes de La ciudad de La Paz.


El crédito lo destinara en la compra y provisión de materiales como ser  cuero, plantillas y otros, que por cercanías a las fiestas de navidad elevan de precio los proveedores.
 
 
Es el tercer  crédito con Impro, y el segundo vía KIVA la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Bernardo lives with his two children with whom he works in his shoe and boot cobbler business located in the center area of La Paz city. He lives on Gral J. Sever street in the Los Andes zone of La Paz city. The loan will be used to buy and stock materials such as leather, insoles, and more, as the upcoming Christmas holidays the suppliers raise their pries. This is the third loan with Impro, and the second through KIVA. The evaluation qualifies him to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy leather, insoles, etc. for his shoe business

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing sells palm oil wholesale and retail. She travels to Anambra and Imo State to purchase palm oil to sell in Lagos State. Blessing says that her customers prefer palm oil from Anambra and Imo State because the palm oil from these states tastes good.

Blessing is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She has been in this business for the past 5 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more palm oil to sell. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance for their kind financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more palm oil to sell

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
La señora Carmen vive en casa propia en la calle Guzmán de Rojas de la zona de Sopocachi, no tiene hijos es mujer sola, la actividad que tiene es la de comerciante ya que tiene una tienda ubicada en la zona de Llojeta, con esta actividad ella se mantiene, el crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital y surtir mejor su tienda con mayor variedad de productos (sodas, dulces, pan, leche, arroz, fideo, etc.) para atraer mas clientela.

El historial de la señora e muy bueno por lo tanto califica para obtener un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Carmen lives in her own home on Guzmán de Rojas Street in the Sopacachi neighborhood. She is single and has no children. She has her own store located in the Llojeta neighborhood, and this is how she earns her income. The loan that she has requested is to increase her capital and better stock her store with a better variety of products (sodas, sweets, bread, milk, rice, noodles, etc.) in order to attract more customers. Her credit history is very good, and because of this she qualifies for a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more products for her grocery store

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Pov E. is 46 years old and lives with her husband and two of her childrE. in the Kampong Cham province. She makes and sells rice noodles in her village and earns about US$7 every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a rice farmer and makes about US$2 a day. The couple also receives support from their two childrE. who work as garment factory workers. Pov E. would like to use this loan to purchase a motorbike for her childrE. to commute to work. This will reduce the amount of money that they spend on public transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Thorn B., 24, is married and lives with her child in the Prey Veng province. She and her husband (pictured here) are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been difficult for them to handle. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Thorn B. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase land to increase her farming production. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase farmland

loans.name: Claveles Blancos Group

texts.es: El Banco Comunal "Claveles Blancos " esta representado por la señora Silvia y conformado por 13 miembros los cuales se dedican a diferentes actividades como a la venta D. ropa, verduras, papa, abarrotes, comida, juegos electrónicos y a la elaboración D. pan. Pese a existir la competencia los socios (as) han sabido salir adelante gracias a su experiencia y a sus ganas D. salir adelante. El destino del financiamiento es para la compra D. materiales e insumos para el incrementar sus ingresos y mejora la calidad D. vida D. sus familias. Los socios (as) ya trabajaron bajo la modalidad D. grupos solidarios por lo que conocen sus ventajas y beneficios en general tienen experiencia en el manejo D. los fondos otorgados y son gente honesta y responsable con sus obligaciones.
texts.en:
The Claveles Blancos (White Carnations) community bank is represented by Silvia. Its 13 members operate a range of businesses selling products such as clothing, vegetables, potatoes, groceries, food, electronic games and making and selling bread. Despite competition, the group's members have forged ahead, relying on their experience and their drive to succeed. The loan will be used to buy goods and supplies that will, in turn, increase their incomes and improve the quality of life of their families. The members have worked within the strictures of community banks before so they know the advantages and benefits of them. Generally, they have experience managing borrowed funds and handle them honestly and responsibly.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital.

loans.name: Emerida

texts.en:
Emerida D. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to open up a bar. Emerida is 27 years old and is married to a nurse. She has three children who all go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a bar

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en: N. Joyce is the leader of Zibula atudde group in Lugazi. She is married with five children and she cares for 10 dependents including providing shelter, food, clothing and general upkeep. Joyce is a coffee dealer and a tailor and she is grateful that the loans have helped her learn how to save for business expansion. She has future plans where by she plans to educate all her children to the top; she wants to renovate her residential house as well as construct another house to rent. She needs another loan (30th loan) to be able to reinvest in her businesses by buying more coffee and more clothing material for her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and clothing material.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose O. is a 32-year-old mother of five children. Her eldest child is 17 and the youngest is 3. She sells small fish in Kisumu that she purchases in Mombasa and Mbita. She is married to an electrician. Her main challenges are the costs associated with transporting her supplies and lack of adequate finance. She is asking for 20,000 KSH ($275 US) to increase her inventory.

Rose recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients. She will also provide reproductive health education, refer patients to local clinics and hospitals, and provide basic health care.

loans.use: To transport fish for her business.

loans.name: Reneda

texts.en:
Reneda Q. is from the village of Gala Ozamiz. She is 55 years old, married and has eight adult-aged children.

To make a living, Reneda grows and sells flowers in the local community. Reneda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Reneda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Reneda has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC.

Reneda is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional flowers to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Reneda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve/expand the business and to support her family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Jarkin

texts.en:
A. Jarkin is 46 years old and married with two children. She started her own business seven years ago because her husband at that time was unemployed. Jarkin sells confectionery like candies, cookies and pastries in the local market. The generated income allows Jarkin to support her family. Jarkin dreams of educating all of her children with higher education.

Today, Jarkin requests 4,000 Somoni for purchasing confectionery to enlarge her range of goods. The income she is planning to spend on the well being of her family as well as for educating her children.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase confectionery to enlarge her range of goods

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma M. is 45 years old, married with four children, and lives at Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental.

Emma has been a member of Paglaum since December 2008 and now is applying for a loan of Php 7,000 to use as additional working capital for her sari-sari (variety) store. She will use the loan to buy additional stock such as laundry items, seasonings, goodies, toiletries and other household items.

Emma hopes to have a successful business with a concrete store and to have all their children finish with a college degree and have a good future.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita P., from the village of Mialin, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, is a 64-year-old married mother of four adult-aged children. To make a living, Pacita raises hogs for sale. Engaged in the business for over 43 years, she earns approximately 5,200.00 PHP a month.

In June 2009, Pacita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 3000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be Pacita's first from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 18 Juillet 1967 à Bamako, Mariam S. est une femme mariée, mère de quatre enfants qui réside avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
   N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales,  elle s’est initiée à l’activité de  commerce d’achat et de vente des pagnes wax et des tissus brodés il y a plus de dix  ans. Elle est beaucoup  appréciée et sollicitée  de sa clientèle, surtout pour la qualité de ses produits.
   Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il à son premier prêt, pour acheter  8 pièces de pagnes UNIWAX, 4 complets de tissus brodés, 5 pièces de pagnes wax REAL et 5 complets de bazin “moins riche” à Bamako et à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
   Elle dispose d’une place au niveau du marché de leur quartier où elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes.
   Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on July 18, 1967 in Bamako, Mariam S. is a married woman, the mother of 4 children, who lives with her husband, her co-spouse and their children in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Not having had the good fortune to make a go of her schooling for socio-economic reasons, she began buying and selling “pagnes” (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) and embroidered cloth more than 10 years ago. She is much appreciated and sought after by her clientele, especially because of the quality of her products.

Wishing to better satisfy this ever growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom she is on her first loan, which will be used to buy 8 lengths of “pagne” of the UNIWAX brand, 4 outfits of embroidered cloth, 5 lengths of “pagne” of the REAL brand, and 5 outfits of “bazin moins riche” (locally dyed damask) in Bamako and Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso).

She has a place in the neighborhood market where she sells her merchandise, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed essentially of women.

With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow her working capital, contribute to covering family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes", embroidered cloth, and damask for resale

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan N. lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She is 30 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice.

Her husband, Mr. Thin Thorn, is a duck breeder who has a business selling duck eggs. He is shown in the picture with her. Since his duck-egg business is doing well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Chan N. decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding to produce more eggs.

loans.use: To buy more ducks to produce more eggs

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A. sells gari (roasted cassava). She goes to the farms to buy cassava and processes it into gari at Abrodzirum near shama-kedzi.

Margaret has received junior high education. She is divorced and has three children. Her husband is into farming. Margaret is responsible for the payment of school fees and the settlement of bills.

Margaret’s loan will enable her to increase her capital to purchase more cassava to make gari. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava to make more gari

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn U. is from the village of Lower Balulang. She is 29 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 2 young children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a  sari-sari (variety) store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of PHP 5000 which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

location.town: Balulang, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Hawa Gull Group

texts.en:
Hawa G. Group is a group of five borrowers led by Hawa G.. She is 53 years old and is married with three children aged 16 to 21 years old, with educational levels of 7th through 9th grade. Hawa and her family live in the Old Road community south of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia, but she works in the Joeba Market in Old Road.

Hawa's business is selling general goods. She buys wholesale goods like soap, candles, detergent, body cream, etc., and sells retail in the Joeba market. She has been running this business for six years and hopes to grow her little shop to a bigger store in order to improve her business. She talks to her customers with a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.

Hawa needs this loan in order to purchase new goods. She dreams of improving the living standard of herself and her family and of giving her children a better education.

loans.use: To buy new goods to improve her business

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna T. is a 29 year old rice farmer. She has a small rice field, which helps her and her husband provide all the needs of their household. In addition to rice, she has started to raise pigs close to their home.  She engages in multiple businesses in order to supplement their daily income. She has been a CEVI client for quite a long time now. She conscientiously pays all her obligations and has maintained a good repayment record in CEVI's micro credit program.

She hopes to grow her business but needs additional capital to do this. She is applying for a loan of Php 9,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to fund her farm and buy the farming necessities. In this way, she is assured to have an abundant harvest on her farm that her family will  enjoy.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Kemishego Development, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
T. Florence has been a farmer since 1990. She is a hardworking and devoted lady. She is 40 years old and married with three children, ages 18, 14 and 13 years old, and she takes care of two dependants. Although she has challenges, like limited capital, she is able to make 300,000/= in profit a month and this helps her take care of her family and contribute to the family's development.

Florence is the leader of her group. She mostly sells agricultural produce and she has been able to win many customers due to her good customer care. She longs to have an expanded business as well as to provide the best education for all her children. Florence needs a loan to help improve her banana plantation by getting more fertilizers and purchasing manure.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and manure

loans.name: Shokir

texts.en:
T. Shokir, a 46-year-old married father of two, breeds calves and sells dairy products to the local people and dairy factories. The difficult circumstances and hardships in his life made him recognize the value of work from a very young age. For about six years he has been purchasing young cattle in the local market, fattening and then selling them. Raising livestock is the main income source in his family. Thus Shokir wakes up early every morning to feed his calves and cows with the goal of selling them at the best price in the local market when they have grown enough. Shokir`s main goal is to provide education for his children, and with this purpose in mind, he has applied for a loan in the amount of 5000 Somoni to buy calves in order to expand his business. Let's support this hard-working man and hold our hands out to help him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes: its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase calves to expand the business.

loans.name: Gladys Ruth

texts.es:
La señora GLADYS RUTH D. P. D. R. tiene 52 años, vive en el distrito deL PORVENIR, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. 
Pertenece al Banco Comunal LIDERESAS EN ACCIÒN. 
La socia presenta estudios superiores D. fisioterapia y rehabilitación, es casada y tiene 4 hijos D. los cuales 3 dependen económicamente D. ella.
Gladys se dedica a la atención D. pacientes en el club D. madres y a la vez es directora D. los wawawasis D. Víctor Raúl. 
Con su primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles comprò medicamentos e implementos para el botiquín  D. su consultorio.
Con su próximo crédito D. 1,000  nuevos soles comprarà medicamentos, gasas, algodón, mercurio , algodón, etc. para ampliar su botiquín.
Ella sueña con comprar una fotocopiadora para poder brindar el servicio D. fotocopiado y así poder obtener mayor cantidad D. dinero para continuar apoyando en la educación D. sus 3 hijos.
texts.en:
Sra. Gladys Ruth D. P. D. R. is 52 years old and lives in the District of El Porvenir, Trujillo Province, Department of La Libertad – Perú. She is a member of the Communal Bank “Lidresas en Acciòn” (Leaders in Action). Gladys has a degree in physiotherapy and rehabilitation. She is married and has four children of whom three are still financially dependent.

Gladys takes care of patients who are part of a parenting club and is also the Director of the Víctor Raúl Day Care Center. With her first loan of 300 soles, she purchased medicines and a first aid kit for her office. This next loan of 1000 soles will be used to buy medicines, gauze, cotton, mercury (Mercurochrome), and other items needed to restock her emergency supplies.

Gladys hopes to buy a photocopier so that she can proviD. duplicating services, thereby earning extra income to support the education for three of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase medicines, gauze, cotton, mercury, etc.

loans.name: Eugenio Eudelon

texts.es:
El señor Eugenio O. tiene 37 años de edad, desde muy pequeño le ha gustado ser comerciante, pues sus padres se dedicaban a la venta de mariscos y el siguió con la misma actividad. 
En la madrugada sale a comprar pescado y camarón al mercado mayorista y hasta las 14h00 se dedica a recorrer en su triciclo las calles del lugar donde vive para vender sus productos. 
Para la venta de camarón don Eugenio invierte US$ 14 y obtiene una ganancia US$ 6, en el pescado invierte US$ 10 y obtiene un 100% de utilidad.   Con el préstamo va a arreglar el baño de su casa. Su meta a futuro es tener un puesto de venta de mariscos en el mercado y terminar de arreglar su casa.
texts.en:
Eugenio O. is 37 years old. Since he was very small he wanted to be a businessman. His parents made a living selling seafood so he went into the family business.
At dawn he sets out to buy fish and shrimp at the wholesale market and then goes about his neighbourhood streets on his three-wheeler selling his products until 2pm.
Eugenio buys the shrimp for US$14 and makes a profit of $6. The fish costs $10 and he makes a 100% profit. He will use the loan to renovate the bathroom in his home. His goals for the future are to have a seafood stand in the market and to finish setting up his house.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair the bathroom in his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying yams and corn

loans.name: Marie Madeleine

texts.fr: Marie Madeleine N. est une femme de 59 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois depuis 8 ans et demi et y a bénéficié de 17 prêts qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés sans difficulté. Elle fait un petit commerce d'effets vestimentaires et de toilette. Son objectif est de soutenir son mari admis à la retraite depuis plus de 5ans dans la prise de la famille, et d'assurer partiellement le payement de la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Marie Madeleine N. is 59 years old, married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” loan group for the past 8 ½ years, and has always managed well and repaid her 17 previous loans without any problems. She runs a small shop retailing articles of clothing and toiletries. Her objective is to assist her husband, retired for over five years, in providing family support, and to pay a portion of her children’s tuition fees.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Promote her commercial activity

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy hair products and other cosmetics

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia is a fashion designer and she designs lovely Nigerian patterns for her customers. She also sells tailoring materials to boost her business. She loves this business because she is able to make additional profits to support her home.

Felicia is married with four children and she is 39 years old. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home.

Felicia’s challenge in her business is funds and she hopes to overcome the challenge. She is requesting a loan of N120,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Kpatagnon

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Lomé au Togo, H. Kpatagnon est mariée à GOMEZ Léopold, un chauffeur. Le couple a deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a neuf ans que la famille s'est installée au quartier Fiégnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Grâce qu revenu que lui procure son activité, Kpatagnon assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la famille. Kpatagnon n'a pas été à l'école. Il y a six ans que Kpatagnon s'est mise à vendre des condiments de sauces, des céréales et divers autres produits (pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomates et de sardine, huile de palme, savons, etc.) à son domicile. Kpatagnon s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé. C'est une bonne cliente de ALIDé, qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Kpatagnon sollicite un troisième prêt, afin d'élargir davantage son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Lomé, Togo, Ms. H. Kpatagnon is married to Mr.  GOMEZ Léopold, a chauffeur.  The couple have two children, who are all in school. Nine years ago, the family settled in the Fiégnon district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Thanks to the income earned by her business, she ensures, along with her husband, that the various family expenses are covered.  Kpatagnon did not attend school.  Six years ago, she started selling sauce condiments, grains, and various other goods (pasta, canned tomatoes and sardines, palm oil, soaps, etc.) out of her home.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and also from Lomé.  She is a good ALIDé client who repays her loans.  She is requesting a third loan in order to expand her business further and to satisfy her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods (canned tomatoes and sardines, palm oil, soaps, pasta)

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Elva

texts.es: la Sra. Elva llego a nuestra oficina con la intencion de solicitar un  prestamo en grupo, pero al final se desanimaron y sacaron con otra persona y se garantizaron ambas, Doña Elva vive en el Barrio los claveles de la zona de la Pampa de la Isla en donde tiene su casita propia en la que vive con su esposo y sus cuatro hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, cuenta con una tiendita de barrio en su mimso domcilio y por las noches vende cena (comida), con su tiendita viene trabajando desde hace 3 años y la venta de comida desde hace 1 año, el dinero solicitado sera para aumentar su capital en la venta de comidas, ya que tiene mucha demanda, su objetivo es llegar a colocar en su mismo domicilio una pension para lo cual le falta la infraestructura, una parte del dinero tambien sera invertido en aquello en la compra de material de construccion. "agradezco a la institucion por haber confiado en mi persona argumentala Sra. Elva.
texts.en:
Elva approached our office with the intention of asking for a group loan. However, in the end they were discouraged and decided instead for a joint loan with just one other person; they act as each other’s guarantor. Elva lives in the Los Claveles neighborhood in Pampa de la Isla zone; she owns her own house where she lives with her husband and four school age children. She has a small neighborhood grocery store in her home and has sold prepared food in the evenings for about a year; she has had her store for about 3 years. The requested funds will be used to increase her food sales because demand is high. Her goal is to set up a small eatery in her home but she lacks infrastructure. Part of the money will be used to buy building materials and supplies. Elva states: “I am grateful to the institution for trusting me.”

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For building materials and supplies.

loans.name: Gennsi

texts.es: Gennsi, es un joven soltero de 21 años, que quiere aprovechar todas las oportunidades que le brinda la vida hasta que cumpla los 40 años, él vive con su madre Ana de 41 años y con su padre Elmer de 43 años en casa de ellos y junto a sus 3 hermanos. En sus campos agrícolas se observa sus extensas plantaciones de café y plátanos, esto se  remonta desde hace 3 años cuando empezó a trabajar junto a su padre, contratando operarios para agilizar la labor agrícola. Dentro de su actividad lo que más disfruta es cosechar los plátanos, porque los recolecta de rama en rama, por otro lado le molesta trasladar largas horas de viaje sus frutos a los mercados en donde no consideran el precio exacto de lo que debería costar su producción. Gennsi, está seguro de la calidad de sus productos por eso siempre encuentra un mejor postor, “si vendo solo lo que me ofrecen no podré ganar lo que valen mis cosechas”, afirma, por eso siempre busca tener amigos compradores mayoristas. Con el tiempo espera comprar sus propias chacras y plantar en grandes cantidades, también quiere construir su casa en la ciudad, pues ya piensa en conformar su familia. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, y como es miembro de la junta directiva, le gusta laborar de manera activa en su grupo comunal y que sus compañeros sean participativos. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará 20 sacos de fertilizantes para proteger sus plantaciones, asimismo desea contratar operarios.
texts.en:
Gennsi is a young, 21 year old man who wants to take advantage of all of the opportunities that life offers him before he turns 40. He lives with his mother, Ana, who is 41, and his father, Elmer, who is 43, and with his three siblings in their home. On their farmland, you can see their extensive plantings of coffee and plantains. He has been doing this for 3 years, when he started to work with his father, hiring workers to facilitate the farmwork. One of the activities he most enjoys is harvesting the plantains, because he collects them bunch by bunch. On the other hand, he dislikes transporting his products for long hours of travel to the markets where they don't consider the exact price that the production should cost. Gennsi is sure of the quality of his products and that is why he always finds the best bidder "if I just sell at what they offer I can't make what my harvests are worth", he affirms. That is why he always seeks to have wholesale purchasing friends. With time, he hopes to buy his own land and plant in large quantities. He also wants to build his house in the city, because he is planning on starting a family. This is his third loan with MFP, and since he is a member of the board of directors, he likes to work actively in his community group and for the other members to participate. With the loan he is asking for, he will buy 20 sacks of fertilizer to protect his plantings, as well as hire workers.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 bags of fertilizer and to hire workers.

loans.name: Agueda Rosa

texts.es: Solicitante con buenas referencias, se dedica al alquiler de cochera para mottotaxis, en una casa de su propiedad.Sus clientes con propietarios de motos de la zona. Ademas su conyugue se dedica a la venta e instalaciones de fluorescentes a domicilio. Cuentan con casa propia de material noble, la cual se encuentran levantando paulatinamente. No presentan endeudamiento en el sistema financiero, con buena calificacion en la SBS.Solicitan el prestamo para terminar de levantar una pared colindante medianera trasera de su casa.
texts.en:
The applicant has good references. She rents out the garage in her house for “mototaxis” (three wheeled motorized vehicles). Her customers own motorcycles in the area. Her life partner sells and installs fluorescent lights in homes. They have their own home, which is made of sturdy material. They are gradually adding on to it. They are not in debt to any financial entity. They have a good score with the SBS, the Peruvian Superintendent of Banks. They are requesting the loan to finish adding on a dividing wall adjacent to the back of their house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a wall in the back of their house

loans.name: Chemwachar

texts.en:
Chemwachar is 54 years old. He is married with no children. He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for 20 years and producing milk and maize, which he sells locally. He is also an agricultural contractor and earns an income from his services to the local people.

His biggest challenge in farming is the fluctuation in the prices of milk and the high cost of farm inputs.

He has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 93,600 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk to sell. The extra income from this loan will assist him meet his basic needs.

In five years time, he hopes to have increased his productivity by 50 percent.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Albin

texts.es:
Albin N. A. es un joven de 23 años de edad  el cual vive con sus Padres en una comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada Mollejones de Platanares, Pérez Zeledón. Mollejones es una comunidad ubicada a 150 kilómetros al sur de la Provincia de San José, la capital de Costa Rica. Se encuentra a 850 metros  sobre el nivel del mar. Ahí se cultivan hortalizas, café y además se desarrollan otras actividades como la crianza de ganado de engorde y de cerdos.


La familia de Albin se ha dedicado toda su vida a la agricultura, pero desde muy joven su espíritu de emprendedor lo llevo a querer tener su propio negocio. Y ya hace 3 anos que monto con su padre su propio Café Internet. Este negocio  le permite tener una fuente de ingreso y seguir sus estudios.

Por ahora Albin  desea obtener un micro crédito por un monto de ¢500 000 (quinientos  mil colones) para comprar una impresora Multifuncional que le permitirá expandir su negocio y abastecer las necesidades de la población de su comunidad, que le han mencionado la falta que hace este servicio. 

Albin  forma parte de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancruce una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será  su primer préstamo y asegura que será de mucho beneficio para su negocio, y espera seguir participando más activamente con la empresa de crédito Comunal.
texts.en:
Albin N. A. is a 23 year old young man who lives with his parents in a rural community in Costa Rica called Mollejones de Platanares, Pérez Zeledón. Mollejones is located 150km south of the San José province, the capital of Costa Rica. It is 850m above sea level. Vegetables and coffee are grown here in addition to raising beef cattle and pigs. Albin's family has been in the farming business his whole life, but from a very early age Albin's entrepreneurial spirit has been his motivation for wanting to have his own business. Three years ago, with his father's help, he opened his own internet café. Albin is requesting a loan for 500,000 colones (Costa Rica's currency) to buy a multi functional printer that will allow him to expand his business and to meet the needs of the people in his community that have called his attention to the lack of this service. Albin is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Bancruce, one of the 100 EDESA member organizations in Costa Rica. This will be his first loan and he is sure that it will be very beneficial for his business. He hopes to continue as an active member of this communal bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a multi functional printer

loans.name: Tayseer

texts.en:
Tayseer, whom we see in the picture above, is a 41-year-old man from Jenin. He is the father of three sons and two daughters. Tayseer and his sons work the land, growing and selling vegetables. However, this business is not providing enough income for the father to pay for the household expenses and his children's education. 

Tayseer decided to start another business where one of the sons could work and help him. One of Tayseer's sons was trained to repair mobile phones, so Tayseer rented a small shop for this business. He took a loan from FATEN to purchase the tools used to repair mobile phones and the exhibition stands used to display them in the shop.

loans.use: Purchase tools and display stands for a mobile phone repair shop

loans.name: Madonna Gale

texts.en: Madonna Gale B. is from the village of Calamagui, San Pablo. She is 35 years old and is married with one infant child. Madonna Gale owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seventeen years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Madonna Gale joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Madonna Gale is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en:
Ganhuyag B. is 36 years old and lives with his mother in Hovd province in western Mongolia. They live together in a traditional Mongolian house-tent called a ger. Ganhuyag operates a metal home goods trading business at the local market in his town. He takes sheet metal and forms many small products such as buckets, washtubs, dustpans, etc., from them. His mother helps to sell the products at their stall in the market. 

Ganhuyag started his business in 2000 and has built a stable operation over the years. His earnings have enabled him to pay half of the money owed on a car he purchased in 2002. Ganhuyag has a very strong work ethic and is a very open-minded person. He says, "I hope to save enough money to build my own house next to my mother's as well as pay the other half owed on my car." Ganhuyag is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of raw materials for his metal products business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of raw materials

loans.name: Sot

texts.en: Sot S. is a 39-year-old married mother who currently lives in the best territory of Battambang in Cambodia. She is a local fish seller. In addition, she sews clothes for her nearby neighbors to make extra profit. Sot S. has a life partner in her husband who is a construction foreman. The family includes two devoted children. Both of them are single and work with their father in the construction sector. Sot S. would like a loan of $600 in order to purchase a secondhand motorcycle which will allow her family to drive to work or anywhere else.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motorcycle

loans.name: Faustino

texts.es:
Faustino de 45 años de edad habita junto a su familia en la Comarca de Puerto Diaz junto a su familia compuesta por su esposa Maria Mora Salablanca y sus 2 hijos de 12 y 15 años de edad.  Desde ha 25 años se dedica a la pesca artesana, pues es la herencia que sus padres le enseñaron desde muy joven.  

Esta solicitando su 3er credito con el objetivo de comprar redes para pesca, pues actualmente tiene deterioradas las que usa para su trabajo.  Cuenta con el apoyo de su familia, pues una vez que Faustino lleva el pescado salen a venderlo a la ciudad y de esta manera obtienen ingresos que le permiten el sustento familiar.

Su mayor sueño es mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia, y crecer mas en su negocio.
texts.en:
Faustino, 45 years old, lives in Comarca de Puerto Diaz with his family, composed of his wife, Maria Mora Salablanca, and their 2 children, a 12 year-old and a 15 year-old.  He began fishing over 25 years ago, when he inherited the profession from his parents, whom taught him the trade when he was very young.  

He is applying for his third loan with the objective of purchasing fishing nets because his current ones are deteriorating.  He relies on the support of his family, who take what he has caught to the city to be sold.  This income is what supports his family.  

His ultimate dream is to improve his family's quality of life and to grow his business.

loans.use: Purchase fishing nets.

loans.name: Ana Jane

texts.en:
Ana Jane D. C. is 38-years old,  married and supports her family by operating 2 business ventures:  a general store and a food vending businesses. She lives in Hda. Tiling, Brgy. San Pablo, Manapla, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her  general store and food vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 7500. 

Ana Jane is now borrowing PHP 23000 so that she  could  continue to fund the businesses operations.   This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 23000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ana Jane aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund Operations

loans.name: Las Flores De San Antonio Group

texts.es:
Dominga es una socia de la alcancía comunal “Las Flores de San Antonio” ella participa más de tres años en este grupo y durante todo este tiempo ha ido mejorando su negocio de a poco tal es así como nos cuenta:
Empecé a trabajar a los 37 años vendiendo quinua y maca con pan queque, mis hijos aún pequeños me acompañaban a cargar las ollas y utensilios para vender desayunos en el mercado de Chosica así estuve dos años; luego tuve que cambiar de negocio a la venta de cerveza en mi casa debido a que tenía que criar a mi hijo pequeño y necesitaba de mis cuidados. Continué vendiendo queque y pudín que yo misma lo preparaba en casa y lo ofrecía a los pobladores de mi zona. Me animé después en hacer comida como caldo de gallida, chaufa, tallarín saltado y gaseosas que era lo que más le gusta a las personas de mi zona; fue este negocio una gran ayuda durante los seis meses que mi esposo no pudo trabajar.
Sustenté con ello los gastos de alimentación para mi familia y ayudar en parte de la educación a mis hijos, dos son profesionales. Con el tiempo adquirí un carrito sanwichero es mi hija quien lo trabaja así nos apoyamos en algunos gastos del hogar. Actualmente sigo vendiendo comida y preparando queque y budines. El préstamo que necesito lo invertiré para hacer el piso de mi casa a fin que se sienten cómodos los comensales; así mismo una mesa y sillas.
texts.en: Dominga is a member of the communal  bank “Las Flores de San Antonio."  She has been a member of this group for 3 years, and during all of this time she has been improving her business gradually.  She tells us, "I began to work when I was 37 years old selling quinoa and maca pancakes.  Later I had to change my business to selling beer from my house, owing to the fact that I had to raise my small child, and he needed my care.  I continued selling cakes and pudding that I prepared in my house and offered to the residents of my area.  Later I was encouraged to make dishes such as chicken soup, chaufa (a Peruvian rice dish),  spaghetti with beef, and to sell soft drinks; these dishes are preferred by the people in my neighborhood.   This business was a great help during the 6 months when my husband was not able to work. With him, I pay for the food expenses for my family and help with part of the educational expenses for my children, two of whom are professionals.  Over time I acquired a sandwich cart; my daughter works with it and helps us with the some of the household expenses.  Now I continue to sell food and prepare cakes and puddings.  I will invest this loan to redo a floor in my house so that my diners can feel comfortable.  In addition, I will buy a table and some chairs.

loans.use: to buy a table and chairs and to refinish the floor of her eatery

loans.name: One Love Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “One Love” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and, consequently, improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Sinnah T.. Sinnah is 28. She was born in Makeni where she currently resides together with her husband and two children. Her husband is a businessman and her children are attending primary school. For five years now, Sinnah has been selling locally dyed cloths called gara lappers. With the help of this loan, Sinnah will buy gara lapper making materials – white cotton cloth, inks, caustic soda, powder, etc. at wholesale to produce dozens of gara cloths to sell.

loans.use: To buy gara lapper making materials – white cotton cloth, inks, caustic soda, powder, etc. at wholesale to produce dozens of gara cloths to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock more bags of beans and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Munavar

texts.en:
Munavar is married with two children. She sells caps and other sportswear in the central city market. Munavar has been in this trade for 5 years. She is very communicative and has many acquaintances in the market. Her enterprising and adventurous spirit has helped her start this venture and stimulate its growth. Munavar is an active hard-worker who works long hours. All her customers give her positive references. We believe her constant desire to see her business expand and grow is her best motivation for prompt loan repayment. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History: Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.en:
Rodrigo B. is from the village of Malunno Norte,Benito Soliven Isabela. He is 45 years old. Rodrigo is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rodrigo owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Rodrigo has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 20000 PHP per harvest.

Rodrigo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodrigo is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Rodrigo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María A. González vive en la cabecera municipal del municipio de Axochiapan en el estado de Morelos, México. Actualmente tiene 70 años no cursó la educación básica. Ella tiene un negocio de abarrotes y va a ocupar el préstamo de KIVA y Fundación Realidad para surtir su negocio, va comprar principalmente productos de la canasta básica para vender en su tienda. Además de productos básicos vende  refrescos, botanas, juguetes y regalos para toda ocasión. Su tienda se llama “tienda mary”. Lleva con su negocio 20 años nos comenta que lo inició por necesidad al quedar viuda tuvo que sacar adelante a sus hijos; inició lavando y planchando ajeno, pero como no le alcanzaba decidió aprender a elaborar queso y crema, ya sobrellevaba la situación económica de su familia cuando decidió además vender un poco de abarrotes afuera de su casa en una mesita y poco a poco fue metiendo mas producto, compró un refrigerador y comenzó a vender refrescos y así fue creciendo su negocio. Después una vecina le platicó de los préstamos de KIVA y Fundación Realidad y pensó que era una buena oportunidad para darle un mayor impulso a su negocio. Des pues compró el terreno en el que actualmente vive y en donde tiene su negocio.
La señora María es viuda tiene 4 hijas y 1 un hijo, todos son casados e independientes, le ayudan dándole dinero periódicamente para sus gastos y a veces para invertir en su tienda. Le llena  de orgullo que todas sus propiedades las ha adquirido con el producto de su trabajo y por eso disfruta atender cada día a sus clientes y hacer todas las actividades de su tienda. |en promedio atiende 50 personas al día, considera que su negocio es popular porque sus clientes encuentran de todo y porque los atiende bien. Algunos de los desafíos que enfrenta su negocio es el aumento de la competencia, pero ella menciona que aun con todo le va bien. Las ganancias de su negocio normalmente las invierten en más mercancía, está planeando ampliar su tienda comprando más vitrinas para exhibir más mercancías y atender mejor a sus clientes. Una parte importante de estos planes los piensa lograr con los préstamos de KIVA y Fundación Realidad.
Le gusta mucho su localidad porque como ella misma comenta “…por eso me gusta mi pueblo (Axochiapan), porque es un lugar de negocios, todo lo que uno ofrece se vende…”  se siente feliz con el otorgamiento de su préstamo porque va a poder llevar a cabo sus metas, sus palabras para el equipo de KIVA son: “…les agradezco por el préstamo que me hicieron y que ayuden a más gente…”
texts.en:
María A. González lives in the center of the municipality of Axochiapan in the state of Morelos, Mexico.  She is 70 years old and did not undertake basic education.  She has a grocery store.  She will use the loan from Kiva and Fundación Realidad to supply her business.  She is going to buy mainly basic items to sell in her store.  In addition to basic items, she sells sodas, snacks, toys, and gifts for all occasions.  Her store is called "Tienda Mary" ("Mary's Store").  She has been in business for 20 years.  She tells us that she started the business out of necessity upon becoming a widow, when she had to provide for her children.  She began by doing washing and ironing, but as this did not bring in enough, she decided to learn to make cheese and cream.  The family's economic situation became bearable when she decided to also sell a few groceries outside of her house on a little table.  Bit by bit, she added more products.  She bought a refrigerator and began to sell sodas, and in this way her business grew.  Later, a neighbor told her about the loans from Kiva and Fundación Realidad, and she thought it was a good opportunity to give her business a bigger push.  Afterwards, she bought the land where she currently lives and where she has her business.

María is a widow and has 4 daughters and 1 son, all married and independent.  They help her by giving her money periodically for her expenses and sometimes they invest in her store.  She is full of pride at the fact that everything she has she acquired with the fruits of her labor, and therefore she enjoys serving her customers each day and doing all of the tasks needed in her store.  On average, she has 50 customers a day.  She thinks her business is profitable because her customers find everything there, and because she provides them with good service.  One of the challenges facing her business is the increase in competition, but she notes that even with everything, she is doing well.  She normally invests the earnings from her business in more merchandise, and she is planning to enlarge her store by buying more display cases to exhibit more merchandise and serve her clients better.  She plans to achieve a significant part of those plans with loans from Kiva and Fundación Realidad.  

She likes her town a lot because, as she herself says, "...that's why I like my town (Axochiapan), because it's a place for businesses, everything one could offer is for sale..."  She is happy about the granting of the loan because it will enable her to achieve her goals.  Her words for the Kiva team are: "...I thank them for the loan they made me, and may they help more people..."

loans.use: To buy soap, bleach, crates of eggs, sodas, purified water, snacks

loans.name: Crice

texts.en: Crice would like a loan to purchase a motorcycle. He has been working in the transport sector for one year. and his dream is to have at least three motorcycles. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda, and is charged with the responsibility of taking care of his one-year-old child. He desires to build a permanent house for the family.

loans.use: Purchase of a motorcycle.

loans.name: Karel Tatiana

texts.es: Karel Tatiana tiene una farmacia hace más de 4 años, esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos por lo que ha sido de mucho provecho.  Sus ventas son al crédito para algunos clientes y de contado para el público en general. Este crédito es para la compra de medicamentos que le han solicitado sus clientes. Ella es una persona muy luchadora por lo que se siente muy feliz de poder contar con negocio que le genere ingresos a su hogar.
texts.en: Karel Tatiana has her pharmacy business for the past 4 years. It is not the first time she accesses a loan and past loans have been very helpful. Her sales are completed on credit for some clients and in cash to the general public. This loan will be used to purchase medications that have been requested by her clients. She is a defiant person and she feels very happy to be able to depend on her business to generate an income for her household.

loans.use: To purchase medications for her pharmacy.

loans.name: David Mukira

texts.en:
David has been selling fish in Naivasha town for the last two years.  He is 46 years old, married to Emmah Wanja, and they have two children.  

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his third loan. He paid back his previous loans well and in good time. He is planning to renovate his food stall and buy more utensils with the loan.

In future, David hopes to turn his fish stall into a restaurant selling different types of food.

loans.use: To renovate his food stall and buy more utensils.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy supplies for her business and help her family live a better life.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam B., 31, is married and resides with her family in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated city in the country. B. is a tailor, earning an income of USD 2 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 75 on food and USD 115 on the other necessary expenses. B. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a new sewing machine to expand the current business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine to expand the current business.

loans.name: Vann

texts.en: Vann P. is a 31-year-old mother who cares for three single children. Vann P. is a recycling seller - she buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods she buys include the oldest things, electric wires, plastic products, bottles, cans, and other used goods. Her husband always assists her in the same business, and they can earn a profit of approximately $5 a day to ensure that their family lives a proper life. Vann P. is looking for a loan to use as capital to buy more used goods for stocking up to re-sell in order to increase her profits. She is going to use the rest of loan fund for repairing her house.

loans.use: To buy more used goods for stocking up to re-sell and to repair her house.

loans.name: Watta

texts.en:
Watta is 40 years old and live in the Paynesville area. She is single and her fiancee works as a contractor for a construction firm. She has three children between the ages of 16-22.
Watta has been selling oil, cream perm, paper etc. for the past 25 years. Sometimes she experience low sales, but most of the time her business is doing well. Watta is requesting a loan to purchase more oil, cream perm, paper etc. for her business. In the future, she hope to buy some land.

loans.use: to purchase more oil, cream perm, paper etc. for her business.

loans.name: Evangelina

texts.es:
A la vivienda de la señora Evangelina le esta haciendo falta la barda al frente de su casa pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para realizar la mejora. 
Es por eso que esta solicitando su cooperación para poder comprar el material que es block, cemento, arena y pagarle a la persona que se encargara de construir la barda.
Pagara el crédito con el ingreso que obtiene como empleada de limpieza de una casa, ya que su esposo se encargara de los gastos familiares con el sueldo que recibe del su trabajo en una compañía de trasportes. Desea la seguridad de su familia.
texts.en:
Evangelina's house needs a wall in front but she doesn't have the money now to build it.  That is why she is requesting your help so that she can buy the construction materials such as blocks, cement and sand, and also to be able to pay the person who will build it.
She will pay off the loan with the money she gets as a cleaning lady in a house now that her husband pays the household expenses with his income from his work at a transportation company.   She wants safety for her family.

loans.use: To construct a wall in front of her house

loans.name: Jibek's Group

texts.en:
Jibek is the treasurer of this group. She is 46 and married to a contractor. Together with her husband, she takes care of a son and a daughter. Both children study at school. The family lives in a rural area. 

In order to earn money to meet the family's needs, Jibek and her husband breed cattle, and they also cultivate agricultural products. This activity made it possible for them to pay the tuition for their children’s education.  

With money received from the loan, Jibek wants to purchase seeds for farming, and it is for this purpose she applied for the loan.  In the future she wants to see her younger children get wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds for farming.

loans.name: Mwanamvita

texts.en:
Mwanamvita is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby.  She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a restaurant business in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of beans, rice and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of beans, rice and cooking oil.

loans.name: Ma.riza

texts.en:
This is Ma. Riza, 28, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She lives with her partner, Arnold, a carpenter, and is a mother to their child. She, together with her partner, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ma. Riza operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Ma. Riza earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of about $10 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a 12,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Ma. Riza hopes that her business will turn into a grocery someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery products and inventory items needed in her variety store.

loans.name: Celia Carlota

texts.es: Celia Carlota. ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas los tres tiempos negocio que ella inicio hace varios años nos cuenta que se siente contenta porque sus clientes han aumentado por esop nececita este credito para la compra de maiz y leña ya que esta convencida que nececita mas capital para trabajar el sueño mas grande de ella es superarse y darles un mejor futuro a sus hijos.
texts.en: Celia Carlota sells tortillas three times a day.  She started her business several years ago and tells us that she feels happy because her number of customers has increased.  She needs this loan to buy corn and firewood as she is certain that she needs more capital in order to work.  Her biggest dream is to do well in life and provide her children with a better future.

loans.use: to buy corn and firewood for her tortilla bakery

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
