Mirtha es casada, tiene 50 años y 2 hijos, Mirtha tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, actividad que realiza todos los días, además Mirtha vende ollas renaware por catalogo.
Mirtha necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de leche, azúcar, arroz.
Los sueños de Mirtha son surtir su negocio y ampliar.
texts.en:
Mirtha is a member of the Buena Suerte ("Good Luck") Village Bank. She is 50 years old and is married with two children. Mirtha has a store in her home, where she sells basic grocery items seven days a week. She also sells Renaware pots by catalog. Mirtha needs a loan of 2000 soles to buy milk, sugar, and rice. Her dreams are to expand her business and to offer a wider variety of merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy milk, sugar and rice

loans.name: Aishat

texts.en: Aishat is 26 years old and married with 2 children. She has a shop where she sells medicine. She has been in business for the past 2 years. She is requesting for the loan of N60,000 to purchase more medical products to sell.  She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell.

loans.name: Gie Saré Doro Group

texts.fr: Nous sommes des habitants de l'écovillage de Saré Doré, qui fait partie de Colufifa et nous sommes dans une zone enclavée, difficile d'accès, car les routes sont impraticable, surtout en période hivernale. C'est pour cela que nous sommes venues solliciter un prêt auprès de votre institution, afin de pouvoir faire face à des difficultés de ravitaillement que connaissent las populations de notre écovillage. Ce stock nous permettra d'avoir sur place une quantité importante de produits de première nécessité. Ainsi nous faciliterons la tâche à tous les riverains qui souhaitent acquérir des produits d'utilité quotidienne et qui ne souffrirons pas le calvaire pour pouvoir se les procurer.
texts.en:
We are residents of the eco-village Saré Doré, which is part of Colufifa. And we are in an isolated area, difficult to reach, because the roads are practically impassable during winter time. This is why we have come to apply for a loan from your institution, so as to be able to cope with supply problems that people are experiencing in our eco-village. This stock of supplies will allow us locally to have significant quantities of basic necessities. And so, we will facilitate the task for all those who live by the water and who wish to acquire every-day goods but who won’t put up with the ordeal of getting supplies.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy domestic goods and foodstuff

loans.name: Olga

texts.en: Olga K. is a 27-year-old married woman with one child. She has a retail shop in the Mengo area and has been operating this business for over two years. She requests a loan so she can offer customers some new items in her store and to buy more stock of existing items such as drinks, rice, plastics, soap, and sugar. She strives to be a good and prosperous business woman.

loans.use: To stock her shop.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is forty years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Dormaa in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Dormaa is a commercial and farming town. Comfort is a trader. She trades in utensils – cooking utensils, bowls, etc. She buys sets of plates, bowls, etc. from Kumasi. Comfort hawks to sell in her community and also treks to nearby communities to sell. She has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy utensils

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 58 years old.  She is widowed and the mother of six children. Two of her children are in school. She always works hard to meet her target. By doing that, she has acquired lots of marketing and selling experience. She is a food vendor and prepares ‘Akyeke’ in front of her house. Akyeke is a local food with its origin from Cote’ de l‘voire in the west Africa region. Grace is the first to start Akyeke preparation in her community, which has seen high patronage. It is prepared from cassava and goes through many processes. With her 25 years of experience, she requests a loan to buy stock such as tomatoes, onions, pepper, cassava etc. She takes delivery of goods from the surrounding villages to prepare her food. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy food items like cabbage, tomatoes, onions, pepper and cassava etc.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma de l’association Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 36 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Massigui, sous préfecture de MASSIGUI, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers et la restauration. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. Elles sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter des habillements pour hommes et femmes et une grande quantité de céréales pour la restauration. Les habillements sont achetés en grande partie à Bamako et à Fana, quant aux céréales et aux condiments alimentaires pour la restauration, ils sont achetés en détail dans les villages environnants et sont revendus au marché de Massigui à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 39 000FCFA  par mois qui sera utilisé pour la nourriture,  la santé et  le réinvestissement dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Sabougnouma group of the Benkadi association are married women who average 36 years of age and 3 children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the Massigui village, in the Massigui sub-prefecture, Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali.

They got acquainted by links of neighborhood and kinship. They sell various items and do catering. Eager to always have financial support for their businesses, these women work with Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They are seeking their twelfth solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans were repaid without problem.

They intend to use this loan to buy men's and women's clothing, and a large quantity of cereals for their catering business. The clothes are purchased mostly in Bamako and Fana, whereas cereals and condiments are purchased in the surrounding villages. They sell at the Massigui market, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

They foresee turning a monthly profit of XOF 39'000 (ca US$ 90) each, to be in part used to provide food and healthcare to their families, and in part reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and cereals

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is 52 years old. She is a widow and has two children who are currently independent.

She says selling of lingerie especially for women is very profitable and therefore she has been selling ladies jean materials and lingerie by hawking for 15 years.

Vida wants to use her loan to buy bales of lingerie and jeans material to increase her inventory and sales for good income.

She believes this loan would help her save some money and rent a shop where she can sell her stock

loans.use: To purchase assorted lingerie in bulk.

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.es:
La señora Anastacia es socia del  Banco Comunal “Manuelas de hoy II”, vive en el distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 45 años de edad y es conviviente.Estudiò primaria completa y tiene 6 hijos.  
Se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales.
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 3 años atrás, y en su Banco Comunal su primer préstamo fue de  S/.500.00 nuevos soles el mismo que le sirvió para la compra de cereales.

Ella solicitará un préstamo de S/.800.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que lo invertirá en la compra  de cereales de la región.

Su deseo para el futuro es tener una casa en Arequipa.

Lo que màs le gusta de su organización son las reuniones.
texts.en:
Anastacia is a member of the Communal Bank “Manuelas de hoy II." She lives in the Ilave district of the El Collao province in the Puno region. She is 45 years old and lives with her partner. She completed primary school and has 6 children. She buys and sells cereals.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos Movement for the past 3 years. Her first Communal Bank loan was for 500 Peruvian soles and was used to purchase cereals.

She is requesting a loan of 800 Peruvian soles that will be used to purchase cereals from the region.

She hopes to someday have a house in Arequipa. Her favorite part of the organization is the meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Huthnance, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase bulk foods

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
La señora Norma es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Bárbara 2” desde hace 5 años, vive en el distrito de Chucuito, provincia y departamento de Puno, tiene 33 años de edad, está casada y tiene 01 hijo. Ella estudió hasta quinto de secundaria, se dedica a la compra y venta de golosinas.

Norma nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, compró más productos (golosinas).

Ella solicitará un crédito  de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, con el cual podrá comprar caramelos, galletas, yogur, gaseosas.

Su sueño para el futuro es mejorar su negocio y así progresar. 

Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es la puntualidad de las socias y de la promotora en cada reunión.
texts.en:
Mrs. Norma has been a partner in the community bank of “Santa Bárbara 2” for the last five years. She lives in the Chucuito district, in the province and neighborhood of Puno. She is 33 years old, married and has one child. She has completed some of her high school studies and makes a living buying and selling candies. Norma tells us about her first loan requested with the Manuela Ramos Movement which was for S/300 Peruvian nuevos soles with which she bought more candy products. She has requested a loan of S/300 Peruvian nuevos soles with which she will buy candies, cookies, yogurt and sodas. Her dreams for the future is to improve her business and with it, get ahead. What she likes best about her community bank is the punctuality of the partners and the promoter at each meeting.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy candies, cookies, yogurts and sodas.

loans.name: Kemeta

texts.en:
Kemeta N. is 32 and married with 4 children (ages 8 months - 16 years).  She owns a business venture, catching & selling ocean-caught fish .  Kemeta has many years of experience in this business.  Kemeta needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 220 tala or US $92 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Kemeta joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Kemeta's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Kemeta N. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.8 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.55 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2.3 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Muborak

texts.ru: Абдуллаева Муборак проживает в районе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 43 года. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Абдуллаева Муборак имеет собственную торговую точку. В области торговли работает более 5 лет. Она продает концелярские товары. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Muborak A. lives in the Tursun-zoda district. She is 43 years old, married and has 2 children. Muborak has her own retail outlet. She has been working in the retail sales field for over 5 years. She sells office supplies. She is requesting a loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Mujeres Con Esperanza 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Secundina is the coordinator of her group, MuJ. Con Esperanza (Women with Hope), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti).

Secundina’s group is located in the areas surrounding Santiago, a large city known for its agricultural production of beef and tobacco, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her longterm partner and their child.

Secundina is excited to be taking her fifth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business repairing and building furniture by purchasing materials for building cabinets, bed bases and dressers.

Secundina will use the profits to further invest in her business by purchasing her own location for her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy materials to build cabinets, bed bases and dressers

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji J.  is currently in the business of selling various items in her shop and is requesting a loan to stock more items to sell. Keji is 28 years old and is married to a clerk. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a wholesale shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more items for sale in her shop

loans.name: Tolibboy

texts.en: I. Tolibboy is 53 years old and lives in Istaravshan town with his wife who helps him with the living expenses since she is a shop keeper. Tolibboy has four sons who also help him. For 15 years, Tolibboy has worked his land which produces potatoes and carrots. At the same time, he raises cattle in his house. His greatest dream is to be able to establish more crops so that he can leave equal parts to his children. He started farming when his parents taught him to work in this way. Tolibboy is requesting financing to buy supplies for his crops in order to get a good yield and sell more in the market. With part of the loan, he will also purchase calves. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Rum

texts.en: Mrs. Rum P. is 63 years old and she is a villager who lives in Boeng Krum Leu village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Yoeun Teang, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow crops to earn a living for their family. Mrs. Rum P. is requesting a loan to dig a well and with the rest of the loan she wants to buy cement to support her well. Mrs. Rum P. is a mother of a child who is a seamstress in the garment factory. Her husband is on the left in the picture.

loans.use: To dig a well on her land

loans.name: Yuvenalis

texts.en:
Mr. B. is 56 years old and married with five children aged 15-30 years, of which two are still attending school. He is a farmer in Bondeni Location in the outskirts of Kitale Town. Yuvenalis has been in the farming business for 10 years and sells his maize and beans in the local market. He depends solely on farming since he had to close down a kiosk he was operating due to bad business. 

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KSh 41,600 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He hopes to venture into zero grazing by increasing the number of dairy cows he owns. He believes that this will increase his income and enable him to live a more comfortable life.

Mr. B. is grateful to Juhudi and hopes that the smallholder farmers will be empowered through products offered by Juhudi.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Dios Es Amor Group

texts.es:
En esta Alcancía Comunal los socios se dedican al comercio lo que les permite mantener a sus familias, como es el caso D. Fidelia elL. venD. ropa en un puesto desD. que se formo un mercado en Huaycan hace varios años, todo el esfuerzo es por sus 4 hijos. ElL. tiene un sueño D. construir su puesto con otro tipo D. material que le permita estabilidad en su negocio.
Ana tiene un pequeño puesto D. ropa en el mercado con los pocos ingresos pueD. mantener a 2 hijos elL. desea invertir mas en su negocio y así obtener mayores ganancias. Con mucho esfuerzo y pensando en L. mejora familiar Josefina pudo aperturar un pequeño bazar y librería en el mercado aunque a veces no tienen muchos ingresos sabe que tiene que seguir trabajando para poder seguir subsistiendo. About EDAPROSPO: EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty
texts.en:
In this Communal bank the members all run businesses that allow them to support their families. One of these is Fidelia. She sell clothes from a store in a market since it was formed in Huaycan a few years ago. All this work is for her four children. She has a dream to build her store with other materials that will give her business stability. Ana has a small clothes store in the market, and with the small earnings she can support her 2 children. She wants to invest more in her business and thus improve her earnings. With much effort and thinking about family improvement, Josefina opened a small store and bookstore in the market. Even though sometimes she does not have much income, she knows she has to keep working to be able to keep surviving. About EDAPROSPO: EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty.

Translated from Spanish by Gerrit Larsen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying products and materials
